marketNews.title: BI Rate Cut by 25 Basis Points, Outside Expectations
marketNews.content:
Bank Indonesia reduced the BI Rate by 25 basis points to 5.75% on Wednesday (15/1), with the deposit facility and lending facility also each falling 25 basis points to 5% and 6.5% respectively. The decision was outside the consensus, which had expected the BI Rate to be held at 6%. Governor Perry Warjiyo said the move considered a balance between rupiah exchange-rate stability and Indonesia’s economic growth. The central bank also cut its 2025 growth outlook from a range of +4.8-5.6% YoY to +4.7-5.5% YoY due to weaker consumption, employment, investment and exports. For 4Q24, the bank projects growth of only +5-5.1% YoY. Inflation for 2025-2026 is expected to stay low at 1.5-3.5% YoY (versus 2024 inflation of 1.57% YoY). The rate cut comes amid a weakening rupiah against the US dollar over recent months, driven by geopolitical uncertainty, the new US administration’s policy direction and a higher-for-longer US rate narrative. The central bank also lowered its expectation for the Fed’s 2025 rate cuts from –50 bps (as of November 2024) to –25 bps, reflecting possible slower disinflation because of higher import duties proposed by the newly elected US President Donald Trump. This expectation aligns with market expectations shown by the CME Fedwatch Tool on Wednesday (15/1). Perry said clearer policy direction from Trump and the Fed will help calm global volatility.

To preserve rupiah stability, Bank Indonesia will continue interventions in the bond market, spot, and domestic non-deliverable forwards, and will optimise the Rupiah Securities (SRBI), Foreign-Currency Sukuk (SUVBI) and Foreign-Currency Securities (SVBI). The central bank is preparing SUVBI and SVBI as additional incentive instruments for foreign-exchange proceeds from natural-resource exports (DHE SDA), alongside existing tools such as foreign-currency term deposits and FX swaps. Previously, Coordinating Minister for Economic Affairs Airlangga Hartarto said the government will revise the minimum placement tenor for DHE SDA from three months to one year, aiming to boost domestic foreign-exchange supplies and ease pressure on the rupiah.

marketNews.title: Key Takeaway: Market Reaction to BI Rate Cut
marketNews.content:
Following the BI Rate cut, the Jakarta Composite Index (IHSG) rose 1.77% at market close, while the rupiah weakened 0.3% to 16,320 per US dollar and the 10-year government bond yield fell 0.4 basis points to 7.272%. The market welcomed the unexpected decision, recording a net foreign inflow of IDR 580 billion—the first inflow since 9 January 2025. Interest-sensitive sectors such as banking (+3.12%) and property (+2.63%) posted strong gains.

- Banking: BBRI (+7.63%), BBNI (+6.78%), BMRI (+6.48%), BBCA (+2.89%)
- Property: CTRA (+7.87%), PWON (+5.26%), BSDE (+5.03%), SMRA (+3.57%)

Investors should watch the US inflation data due on Wednesday (15/1), which could add further pressure on the rupiah.

marketNews.title: Bank Credit Growth Slows to 10.39% YoY in 12M24
marketNews.content: Bank Indonesia reported that bank credit growth slowed to +10.39% YoY over the 12-month period ending December 2024 (down from +10.79% YoY in the prior 11-month period), marking the slowest growth in 13 months while still within the bank’s target range of +10-12%. Investment credit grew +13.62% YoY, consumer credit +10.61% YoY, and working-capital credit +8.35% YoY. Sharia financing grew +9.87% YoY and micro-SME credit rose +3.37% YoY. The central bank projects credit growth of +11-13% YoY in 2025.

marketNews.title: Gaikindo Projects 2025 Vehicle Sales of 750,000-900,000 Units
marketNews.content: The Indonesian Automotive Association (Gaikindo) Secretary General Kukuh Kumara said on Tuesday (14/1) that the association targets vehicle sales of 750,000-900,000 units in 2025 (versus 2024 wholesales of 865,723 units). The target reflects economic uncertainty, a VAT increase to 12%, and the implementation of an op-tax. The target follows comments by Gaikindo I Chairman Jongkie Sugiarto, who said the association remains optimistic that 2025 wholesale vehicle sales will recover to 1 million units.

marketNews.title: OJK Announces Housing-Finance Policy Relaxations
marketNews.content: The Financial Services Authority (OJK) announced on Tuesday (14/1) a set of housing-finance policy relaxations to support the 3 million-unit per year housing program: (1) mortgage quality can be assessed solely on payment punctuality, (2) a low risk-weight of 20% based on loan-to-value, and (3) the removal of the ban on land-acquisition/processing credit that has been in force since 1 January 2023. The regulator also clarified that no OJK regulation prohibits granting credit to borrowers with non-performing loan histories.

marketNews.title: Government Refutes Rumor of Raising DHE SDA Minimum to 50%
marketNews.content: Coordinating Minister for Economic Affairs Airlangga Hartarto denied reports that the government plans to raise the minimum placement ratio of natural-resource export proceeds (DHE SDA) to 50% of the minimum 30%. He said the government is still discussing the ratio, and the earlier rumor of raising the ratio and extending the minimum placement tenor from three months to six-12 months with a 4.48% interest incentive was unfounded. The minister confirmed the government will instead revise the minimum placement tenor from three months to one year.

marketNews.title: Indonesia Trade Surplus Slows to US$2.24 Billion in December 2024
marketNews.content: Indonesia’s trade surplus narrowed to US$2.24 billion in December 2024 (down from US$3.29 billion in December 2023 and US$4.37 billion in November 2024), missing the consensus forecast of US$3.79 billion. The decline was driven by an 11.07% YoY surge in imports while exports grew only 4.78% YoY. Cumulatively in 2024, the trade surplus fell to US$31.04 billion (versus US$36.89 billion in 2023) as imports (+5.31% YoY) outpaced export growth (+2.29% YoY).

marketNews.title: U.S. Announces AI Chip Export Restrictions, Indonesia Listed Among Restricted Countries
marketNews.content: The United States announced new export restrictions on artificial-intelligence chips and related technologies to dozens of countries, no longer limited to a small list of long-standing adversaries. The measure aims to keep “the world’s AI on a U.S.-led path” and to prevent hostile actors from using AI against the United States. Eighteen allied and partner nations will be exempt. The rule is now in a comment period and will take effect within 120 days. Indonesian media reported that Indonesia falls into the limited-access category under the policy.

marketNews.title: Indonesia Poverty Rate Falls to 8.57% in September 2024
marketNews.content: The share of Indonesians living in poverty fell to 8.57% in September 2024, a decline of 0.46 percentage points from March 2024 and 0.79 points from March 2023. However, the Gini ratio rose slightly to 0.381 in September 2024, up 0.002 points from March 2024 though down 0.007 points from March 2023.

tickerNews.title: CTRA: Marketing Sales +8% YoY in 2024, 99.2% of Target
tickerNews.content: Ciputra Development reported marketing sales of IDR 2.3 trillion in 4Q24 (-10% QoQ, -4% YoY). The full-year 2024 marketing sales reached IDR 11.02 trillion, an 8% YoY increase and 99.2% of the IDR 11.1 trillion target. Growth was driven by a strong performance in Sumatra, where marketing sales rose to IDR 2.1 trillion (+85% YoY). Segmentally, landed houses and land sales contributed 82% of total 2024 marketing sales, followed by shophouses (13%), apartments (3%) and offices (2%).

tickerNews.title: CMNP: Clarifies No Shareholder Transfer Notice Received
tickerNews.content: Citra Marga Nusaphala Persada (CMNP) clarified to the IDX that it has not received any notice or correspondence from shareholders or the Salim Group regarding a proposed main-shareholder transfer. The clarification follows a statement by Salim Group’s Jusuf Hamka last week that the group intended to become the main shareholder of CMNP, with the transfer process currently underway. Hamka also noted that CMNP’s President Director Arief Budhy Hardono has long been active in the Salim Group.

tickerNews.title: INTP: Cement Sales Volume Up 2% YoY in December 2024
tickerNews.content: Indocement Tunggal Prakarsa (INTP) recorded a +2% YoY increase in cement sales volume (including Semen Grobogan) in December 2024, lifting its market share to 30.6% (up from 26.4% in December 2023) as industry-wide sales fell 12% YoY. The December gain was driven by Java (+4.1% YoY), with Central Java posting a +49% YoY surge thanks to the Semen Grobogan consolidation. Annual cement sales grew 8.4% YoY to 18.9 million tonnes, and 4Q24 sales rose 5.5% YoY to 5.2 million tonnes. Bulk-bag cement volume grew 29% YoY in 2024, while bagged cement grew 1.1% YoY.

tickerNews.title: HEAL: Director-Owner Purchases 1.9 Million Shares at IDR 1,608
tickerNews.content: Medical-device group Medikaloka Hermina’s director-owner Yulisar Khiat bought 1.9 million HEAL shares at an average price of IDR 1,608 per share on 7 January 2025, totaling about IDR 3 billion. His ownership rose from 12.765% to 12.778%.

tickerNews.title: HGII: 25% Stake Acquisition by Shikoku Electric Nears Completion
tickerNews.content: Hero Global Investment (HGII) disclosed that the conditions for acquiring a 25% stake by Shikoku Electric Power Company (Yonden Group, TYO: 9507) have been fulfilled, allowing the transaction to close in a few days. Yonden will purchase 1.62 billion HGII shares at the IPO price of IDR 200 per share from the founding shareholders. The company aims to operate 100 MW of new renewable-energy capacity by 2031.

tickerNews.title: HAIS: Targets 5-10% YoY Revenue and Net-Profit Growth in 2025
tickerNews.content: Hasnur Internasional Shipping (HAIS) projected a 5-10% YoY increase in both revenue and net profit for 2025, citing expected higher demand for haulage services, a planned fleet expansion and strategic-partner collaborations. The company plans to add four tugboats and barges in 2025, with a capital expenditure budget of roughly IDR 260 billion (versus IDR 250-300 billion in 2024).

tickerNews.title: Bank Indonesia Credit Growth Slows Further in 12M24
tickerNews.content: Bank Indonesia reported that credit to the banking sector grew 10.39% YoY over the 12-month period ending December 2024, the slowest pace in 13 months but still within the bank’s 10-12% target. Investment-credit growth was +13.62% YoY, consumer credit +10.61% YoY, and working-capital credit +8.35% YoY. Sharia financing grew +9.87% YoY and micro-SME credit rose +3.37% YoY. The central bank projects credit growth of +11-13% YoY in 2025.

tickerNews.title: Gaikindo Targets 750-900k Vehicle Sales in 2025
tickerNews.content: The Indonesian Automotive Association (Gaikindo) said on Tuesday (14/1) that it targets a vehicle-sales range of 750,000-900,000 units in 2025, compared with 2024 wholesale sales of 865,723 units. The target reflects economic-uncertainty concerns, a VAT increase to 12%, and the implementation of an op-tax. The outlook follows I-Gaikindo Chairman Jongkie Sugiarto’s comment that the association remains optimistic that 2025 wholesale vehicle sales will recover to about 1 million units.
